content.webTitle: WA premier says Tony Abbott's 'lifestyle choice' comment was unfortunate

fields.headline: WA premier says Tony Abbott's 'lifestyle choice' comment was unfortunate
fields.bodyText: The Western Australian premier, Colin Barnett, has described prime minister Tony Abbott’s characterisation of remote Aboriginal communities as a “lifestyle choice” as an “unfortunate choice of words”. However, he told ABC news in Perth on Wednesday that Abbott had a strong commitment to Indigenous issues. Abbott has received widespread criticism for the remark, which he made while defending the Barnett government’s proposed “closure” of up to 150 of Western Australia’s 274 communities. Barnett foreshadowed the plan after the federal government announced it would withdraw funding from essential services in those communities, leaving that responsibility and a $90m transitional fund with the state. Respected Western Australian elder and Yamatji-Marlpa Aboriginal co-chair, Doris Eaton, said she was angry at comments made by both Abbott and Barnett over the closures, saying governments should spend time in individual communities if they wanted to close the gap between Indigenous and non-Indigenous outcomes in Australia. Mrs Eaton said it was disappointing to hear living on traditional country, which she said was central to Aboriginal identity, dismissed as a “lifestyle choice”. “We are not a tenant on our own country,” Mrs Eaton said. “It’s not about lifestyle choices. It’s about culturally living on country.” “Our ancestors walked this land and so we are going to walk this land.” she said. “You can’t just punish people because they are living on the land, that’s where they are from. We are not just shifted here from the moon.” Mrs Eaton, a Nyamal woman who lives in Yandeyarra, a remote Aboriginal community about 100km south of Port Hedland, told Guardian Australia she was concerned the push to close communities was an attempt to weaken cultural - and therefore legal - ties to land. “It’s very scary,” she said. “They took the land off us, they took the kids off us, now they are going back to the same route that they done, moving people off their land. “The saddest part (about native title) was we have got to prove that we are Aboriginal people that are connected to the land. And now we have to do it all over again.” The National Native Title Council’s chief executive, Brian Wyatt, said demands placed on native title claimants in Western Australian to prove an ongoing cultural connection to country were the highest in Australia, which made it “very difficult” to prove native title unless claimants lived on their country. “People have spent years fighting for their native title rights in court where they have to prove an ongoing connection to their country only to have governments deliberately trying to sever those ties by removing people from their cultural lands,” Wyatt said. “This is outrageous and frankly very close to threatening our cultural genocide.” The federal Indigenous affairs minister, Nigel Scullion, said that Abbott’s description of living on remote communities as “lifestyle choices” was a “mistake” and would make his job harder. Abbott defended his record on Indigenous affairs to reporters in Mount Gambier in South Australia on Wednesday. “I’m very comfortable with my credentials when it comes to doing the right thing by the Aboriginal people of Australia,” he said. Barnett has also received criticism in Western Australia for again linking the closure of remote communities to child sex abuse. “Children aren’t attending school, young children are being abused both physically and sexually, there are no employment opportunities, and I cannot look the people of Western Australia in the face and say, as premier, I am going to ignore that,” he told ABC news on Wednesday. The National Native Title Council, WA opposition and land councils have all accused the government of generalising problems in remote communities and using child sex abuse as a foil for what remains a financial decision.
